title: Religious Verse
description: This is the only extant calligraphy by the Chinese priest Longyan Dezhen. This calligraphy was created in response to a request from the Japanese priest Mumu Issei, who studied in China.

title: Melon and Insects
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on paper
description: Piling, Changzhou in Jiangsu province was the center of insect and grasses paintings in China. This work was an early clue for scholars in the confirmation of the existence of insect and grasses paintings in Piling.

title: Clay Figure of an Officer
description: It was customary during China's Northern Wei dynasty to place large numbers of clay figurines in tombs. This figurine, with its emphasized smooth flatness and beautiful expression, is typical of Northern Wei figurines.

title: Four-storied Pavilion in Green Glaze
description: Green glazed ceramics were popular during the Han dynasty. This work reflects the lifestyles of that period.

title: Squared Yi with Taotie Design
description: This bronze is small in scale and extremely finely finished. This type of bronze vessel was used in ancient China to offer wine or food to the gods.

title: Double-Ram Zun
country: China  probably Hunan province, 13th-11th centuries B.C.
description: This form, with a ram on each side of a cylindrical wine vessel (zun) with a wide mouth, is a rarity among the ritual vessels used to making offerings to the gods or ancestors in ancient China. With the one from the collection of The British Museum, the only two extant examples of double-ram zun are confirmed in the world.

title: Zun with Taotie Design
description: This bronze vessel is thought to have been excavated from the tomb of a Shang dynasty king. Production of this vessel shape began around that period and continued across the millennia to China`s last imperal dynasty, the Qing.

title: Three Squared He with Taotie Design
description: This ritual bronze vessels created during China's Shang dynasty are extremely rare example of a set made up of three pieces.

title: Fragment of Shokkō-kin, Warp-faced Compound Tabby
description: Various types of Buddhist ecclesiastical cloths handed down in Hōryū-ji are known. They are characterized by the bright red ground.

title: Box with Landscape and a Pavilion Design
description: Carved lacquer wares were highly prized in Japan from the Kamakura through Muromachi periods. Examples, as here, of Yongle era carved lacquer, were particularly desirable amongst such carved lacquer works.

title: Tray with Peony Design
description: This tray is made of so-called carved red lacquer.  Large peonies adorns the middle of the tray. The back of the tray is inscribed in needle carving script " Da ming Yongle nianzhi (Made in the great Ming dynasty, Yongle era) ".  This tray was made for use by the Ming imperial court.

title: Box with a Pavilion and Figures Design
medium: Lacquer on wood with mother-of-pearl inlay
description: This mother-of-pearl box was made in the Yuan dynasty. Thin shells were cut into small complex shapes and used to create the decoration. The top of the box lid is decorated with a scene of immortal women enjoying a banquet.

title: Bowl with Three White Fruits Design
description: This bowl with pale brown color glaze has a slightly turned out mouth rim. Three places on the torso are marked with three fruit motifs (pomegranate, peach and lychee) left in white reserve.

title: Bowl with Three Fishes Design
description: Three fish motifs in red glaze are set against a pure white porcelain ground. Close examination reveals that the fish details were worked in incised lines.

title: Dish with Magnolia Design
description: This dish is decorated with white magnolia branches and blossoms set against the blue ground, which gives the entire dish a refreshingly clear mood.

title: Dish with Flower Basket Design
description: This thickly potted flat dish has its rim turned back. A flowers motif fills the interior surface in fine-grained. The geometrical pattern is somehow reminiscent of so-called shonzui ware designs.

title: Large Dish with Flower and Plant Design
description: During the early Ming dynasty the trend for large-scale wares made in either underglaze blue porcelain or celadon was continued from the Yuan dynasty. While the work is unsigned, it is thought to date from the Yongle era.

title: Vase in Meiping Style with Dragon and Phoenix Design
description: Yuan dynasty underglaze blue porcelain wares were made for export to Islamic countries. Many of these wares were large in scale and had decorative motifs that covered the entire vessel.

title: Tea Container, named Matsuya
country: China Southern Song - Yuan dynasties, 13th-14th centuries
description: This katatsuki shape tea container was handed down in the Nara lacquer ware artist Matsuya family and it has hence come to be known as the Matsuya Katatsuki. This is relatively short for the katatsuki type, but this lower slope adds to the imposingly dignified sensibility of the work.

title: Vase with Cylindrical Body, named Ōuchitsutsu
description: This vase has a hole cut into its back surface and is fitted with a metal attachment so that it can be used as a hanging flower vase. This work is a masterpiece of the so-called kinuta celadon form.

title: Vase with Tall Neck
description: The so-called "bamboo shoot" shaped vase type has a long neck and a swelling torso base surrounded by several protruding bands. This vase has a particularly pleasing glaze tone and shape, and is thus considered one of the finest examples of this vase type.

title: Foliated Dish with Carved Lotus Flower Design
description: Overall the bowl is shaped like a flower. The interior of the bowl is covered with a deeply etched, so-called "one-sided carving" lotus blossom design.

title: Large Jar with Applied Ornaments
country: China Northern Qi - Sui dynasties, 6th century
description: This large jar coated in a green glaze has palmettes, celestial women and other designs attached to its surface, which emphasize its exotic West Asian style.

title: Jar with Chicken-headed Spout
description: This jar has a chicken-headed spout and was a new vessel type that appeared at the Yuezhou Kilns. Celadon glazes in either a dark green color or yellowish tinged color characterize early examples of the type.

title: Flower Vase with Handles in the Shape of Elephant Heads
country: China Southern Song - Ming dynasties, 12th-14th centuries
description: There are many examples of Chinese bronzes from the Song dynasty through the Qing dynasty that have been used in Japan as flower vases. This work was used as a flower vase at a flower exhibition held in 1665. This flower vase was owned by the Tokugawa shogunal family.

title: Mirror with Parkeets and Grapes Design
description: This mirror dates to the early Tang dynasty. The grape and vining plant motif was brought to China from West Asia during the Han dynasty, becoming a poplar decorative motif from the early Tang to the high Tang. Grapes are considered an auspicious motif symbokizing fertility.

title: Head of a Seated Bosatsu (Bodhisattva)
description: This is the head of a Bodhisattva image that originally decorated the north wall of Cave 21 at the Tianlongshan caves in China's Shanxi province. The face with its sense of mass reveals the typical sculptural style of the Tang dynasty, considered the pinnacle of cave creation at the Tianlongshan cave site.

title: Eleven-headed Guanyin (Ekadasamukha)
description: This image is one of a group of relief-carved stone Buddhist plinths from Huatasi temple, Xian (also known as Baoqingsi). The symmetrically arranged body and the flowing drapery lines are particularly beautiful, making this an important fundamental piece in the study of Chinese early Tang period Buddhist sculpture.

title: Standing Buddha
description: This work is considered a major masterpiece of large-scale marble Buddhist sculpture made in the late Nortern Qi dynasty. The complete state of the image's dais is also noteworthy. The unusually large head and slight smile give a strong impression to its viewers.

title: Seated Sakyamuni and Prabhutaratna
description: This is a typical example of the two-figure Buddhist images created during the Northern Wei dynasty. The inscription explains that this was created as part of a memorial service for deceased parents. The powerful carving and size of the work make it a renowned example of its kind.

title: Budai and Jiang Mohe in Discussing Buddhism
artist: By Yintuoluo, with inscription by Chishi Fanqi
description: The unusual painting style of this work blends lines drawn with a worn brush with dark black ink, while the figure expression is Zen-like in its extraordinary rendition.

title: Sparrows on Bamboo in the Rain
description: Two sparrows sit on a dead tree branch, slowing getting soaked in the rain. A sense of dampness pervades the painting.

title: Fishing Village at Sunset
description: This landscape of a fishing village at dusk shows a splendid use of the diverse effects possible in ink painting. This is a masterpiece by Muqi, a Zen priest-painter of late Southern Song dynasty.

title: Mountain Landscape at Sunset
artist: By Ma Lin, with inscription by Empelor Lizong
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and slight color on silk
description: This is a superb example of Southern Song dynasty academic landscape painting, created in a simple composition based on diagonal lines and cautiously exact brushwork.

title: Quail
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on silk
description: The intricacy of the depiction and carefully arranged composition give this quail painting a sense of realism. This work is renowned as a major example of Song dynasty bird and flower painting.
